main_text:
Lady Anne Conway (nee Anne Finch) was one of a tiny minority of
seventeenth-century women who was able to pursue an interest in
philosophy. She was associated with the Cambridge Platonists,
particularly Henry More (1614–1687). Her only surviving
treatise, Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern
Philosophy, was published posthumously and anonymously in 1690.
This propounds a vitalist ontology of spirit, derived from the
attributes of God, which she sets out in opposition to More,
Descartes, Hobbes and Spinoza. Her philosophy was received favorably
by Leibniz.
